image:image.image:title: Unicycling while getting married
Nepal – an Asian country bordering India and Tibet
An example of one of their health campaigns.
A market within the Mbabane bus rank
Roasted street corn
Indoor lizard eating a bug
Wonderful breakfast from our landlords when power went out!
Mural I like. Click to zoom!
A pickup truck full of chickens out and about
Birds&#8217; nest on the ground&#8230;
Bird nests still in the tree
Baby veggies!
Grandma is wearing slippers under that long dress to keep her feet warm. Saili is on the right.
Look at all that corn by Yuki&#8217;s place. We&#8217;re basically in the Midwest!
Example of a good simple breakfast
Nepali size 2XL is on the small side for Gabriel.
The gas stove we bought about 2 months in
Damian standing in our very bare kitchen
Our induction burner with a tamagoyaki pan and some grease on it
Our little counter top three in one oven
Home made meat sauce
Yawning with cafe dog
There was another one, too
And they hung out with Gabriel
Mouthy Girl! She lives right outside our house, and she endearingly hangs her mouth open all the time. Lately, she’s been licking more than nipping.
We made it!
Locally referred to as Nikolaido-do (Home of Nicholas)
Hot? Cold? They got you covered!
Leaving the station (don&#8217;t worry, not ours!)
Looking from the street to the bed and breakfast. We are on the right side around back.
Random internet picture with a big pile of ginger.
*Ginger root, not quite edible yet&#8230;. *
*All peeled! *
*Lilly helped with this picture&#8230;.* Ginger all sliced
*All packed in and ready to go! *
*You can already see the ginger is turning the liquid a slight pinkish color*
*Final product, more pink! *
*The ginger developed a slight pink color, younger ginger would get more color. *
Himalayan Java Coffee is a chain that was founded in Nepal. They&#8217;ve even expanded to the US now.
We were told that the grapefruit peels should go on our heads, but I am highly suspicious about this&#8211;only the foreigners wore grapefruit hats!
What, how else would you transport your furniture?
Boudha Community Chorale
All set up at Utpala Cafe
We don&#8217;t have any more photos of swing club, so here&#8217;s Mouthy Girl.
Look at those sources. Am I a real scholar now?
Our room
Proof that our desk was once clean
Third-floor living room
A fancy version of the typical Nepali bathroom: bidet, spigot, and no shower curtain. We bought the toilet paper ourselves.
View from the roof, right above our room
The shrine is at the very top of the stairs.

Meals are no-phone zones, so I snuck this picture when Grandma left the room mid-meal. I mixed together my dal, bhat, and tarkari on the bottom. At the top from left to right, you can see crunchy seasoned soybeans, pea salad with ginger and vinegar, and &#8220;baby French fries&#8221; (as Gabriel calls them).
Dining room table
Maybe it’s a good thing Gabriel isn’t expected to cook&#8230; the kitchen is a bit small for him!
I felt a little like we were a fellowship of sorts&#8230;
Such a beautiful valley
Rolling hills all over
Sitting on a lower part of Sibebe Rock looking down
Looking across from Sibebe Rock. We&#8217;re at the highest point
*Little herbs growing in the landlords’ garden. The garden, and the path to the garden, are new and under construction.*
*This is a park somewhat nearby.&nbsp; I was amazed by the color of the flowers on these beautiful trees.*
Night view looking down towards Mbabane
Okay, well maybe not as busy as these ladies. They were both turbo-walking, one while breastfeeding and the other while balancing brooms on her head! Very impressive!
These aren&#8217;t actually vendors near where we work in the city, but the stalls are a similar setup.
Walking up the driveway to our apartment. Ours is actually behind the new unit (just completed!) that you see on the left.
All clean!
Lots of steps. Lots of statues with offerings. Lots of prayer flags.
Lots of monkeys.
This is one of Dr. Barstow&#8217;s favorite Buddha statues in the world, so I took a picture.
I think this picture says it all&#8230;
88 volumes of manga
Manga in bags in our hallway
It&#8217;s HOT in Atlanta!
Crazy weather we&#8217;re having&#8230;
The font of St. John the Theologian in Ishinomaki
Interior of St. John the Theologian. The iconostasis is quite old and the iconography shows some age. Still very pretty though!
Church in Sanuma, they like the grape pattern I guess. Church of the Transfiguration
The exterior of the Church of the Transfiguration in Takashimizu, someone biked
My lovely wife and the exterior of the church of St. Isaiah in Wakuya
Walking into the church, Matushka is peaking out on the right
The exterior of the new building as seen from their hall
*Right after the bishop entered the building, everyone walked to the front and they sang a bunch of stuff. *
Things happening at the doors to the church.
Eagle rug
The protodeacon wrangling the oversized gospel.
Eis pola eti déspota!
The hall we ate in and listened to speeches in
A somewhat cleaner view of the iconostasis
See? It&#8217;s white. Home to around 500 monks.
You can see the raised platform for the Khenpo to sit on, and the adjacent pad on the floor for the translator.
Another bonus: epic views of the Himalayan foothills!
The wooden benches are not to be sat upon or even stepped over, since they&#8217;re used for studying religious texts.
Orthodox Christian wedding rings, Buddhist sacred thread from the nunnery, and Hindu tikka+grass+money+apple… we’re just getting showered with blessings!
*We got to try out a Dashain swing! Note that the bamboo plants are firmly planted in the ground, so the swing can be deconstructed and reconstructed from the same living plants next year.*

*On the way to the repair place, we came across this arch. Xi Jinping came to visit a couple days ago — he’s the first Chinese leader to visit Nepal since 1996. We were probably only a couple miles away from him. The countries’ relationship is fascinating, we’re worried on behalf of the Tibetan refugees in our community, and we’ll leave it at that.*

A super Nepali scene: flag, motorcycle, Dashain swing. A temple and bodhi tree (the same species as the tree the Buddha gained enlightenment under) are just out of frame. We could see lots of hills around Kathmandu Valley, several religious buildings on the hillside, and even the stupa and RYI. However, we’ll need to go in search of Himalayan peak views some other time.
Sorry, most of the nunnery photos are currently inaccessible because of my phone.
It was wonderful to see rural landscapes for a change!
*Did we mention it was pretty?*
*Yuki, Sameer, Tia, and Gabriel in an awesome corridor formed by a mossy wall and a bamboo grove*
*The aforementioned Tibetan family hanging up prayer flags*
*This monkey followed us for quite some time. I grabbed a rock just in case we needed to defend ourselves.*
*Beautifully lit views helped us get through the last few miles*.
Picture of a busy crossing in Sendai Sunday afternoon
The cathedral in Sendai, called a cathedral because this is the Bishop&#8217;s home base
A view of one of the shopping streets we wandered down
A Shinto shrine directly off one of the shopping streets. Like a church in a mall, very surprising!
Damian charming a couple residents of the cat cafe
Damian grilling our lunch in the table
A truly huge original 200 ish year old map of Miyagi. Damian for scale.
Original armor worn by Date Masamune.
Period clothing, with Damian for scale.
A replica of the ship they took to Mexico, the San Juan Bautista
Catholic priests robes, ostensibly belonged to one of the missionaries, it maybe brought back from Rome
The Salvation Army clinic. The entrance is the large opening. Walking up the steps you can go straight into a chapel our go inside the clinic to the left.
Sorry for the bad shot. For comparison, E15 (Emalengeni) is currently about $1US.
Fire instructions sign in the clinic, each rule in English and SiSwati.

Walking towards work. The Ministry office is on the left. Nando&#8217;s Chicken restaurant is on the right and has great food! Walking up the street further right past Nando&#8217;s is a building where our second office is (FEI).
Assortment of animal skins sold outside of a traditional shop in the same building as our office.
Lots of pickup trucks in the area, especially in the parking lot at work, have international partnership logos on them.
Kindling and firewood for roasted corn sold along the road. Quite yummy and inexpensive!
Local man sculpting busts out of the hillside. I&#8217;m not sure why&#8230;
The Jewel of the Singapore airport
The plants are beautiful from above!
Internal courtyard at Raffles
This was rather expensive&#8230;
This is what an international booze collection looks like
Inside was a squat toilet and no toilet paper.
Rice fields across from our apartment on Sunday. These fields are always dry, so it was weird to look out and see a lake!
One end of the parking lot at Daily Port, a grocery store we frequent.
One of the many emergency alerts we got.

Temporary barrier put across a walkway down to the river front. There&#8217;s usually a walking path down a ways and two long flights of stairs down to the river! We&#8217;ll try to get a good picture at some point when we&#8217;ve had some time to dry out so you can compare the river.
Very flooded road
Even more flooded road!

This was our first introduction to Swazi Fire. They served the hot sauce during our training week. It was sitting innocently at the end of the table in an unlabelled bowl. I thought to myself, I like salsa… Wow, nope! I quickly learned that they are not kidding around with their hot sauce! A tiny amount goes a long way!
There&#8217;s plenty of literal fires though too! They burn small areas to clear away the brush and reduce the chance of a bigger more dangerous fire.
This fire started burning through the highway signposts!
The plants seem pretty accustomed to the fires.
See? Happy new growth just in time for the start of the rainy season!
&#8230;the circle of liiiiife! ♪♪

Eswatini is also where the Kniphofia plant comes from. For those who don&#8217;t know, in Oregon people plant them in their flower gardens and call them Red Hot Pokers. Get it? It&#8217;s another type of Swazi Fire!!! 😅
This is not really on topic, but it&#8217;s a pretty flower that we see along the roadside on our walk to work. Also, it reminds me of a little flame. I don&#8217;t know the name though.
Speaking of our walk to work, here is a picture looking out across the street from the building where I usually work.
Last week one of our meetings was at the UN building. Arian was very flattered to be mistaken for 007!
I was impressed by how cheerfully decorated the building is inside. It&#8217;s very different from the UN building in Geneva, Switzerland!
Even the lizards are colorful here. These little guys with the turquoise blue heads are pretty common.

Back at the office, here is a truck with the logo and name of the health information system that we are here to help improve. They use this truck to drive out to remote health facilities and support the system users. One type of vehicle that neither of us have seen yet &#8211; a firetruck!
The turkey only fit when we removed the drawers and had it pushed all the way back
And the turkey just barely fitting in our oven! We had to cover the top with foil after a bit because it was too close to the heating elements and was just starting to burn.
*Ghee bath for the turkey after it had roasted for a while. Never made ghee like this before, only super huge quantities for Greek Fest. *
*Final image before carving and serving. I think it turned out pretty well all things considered!*
*The apple cobbler Lilly made! Yum!*
*Green Japanese &#8220;pumpkin&#8221;*
*Lilly&#8217;s pie crust, an important first step and challenging when there&#8217;s a giant turkey in the fridge. *
*Pie #1, though we burned it a bit&#8230; Still tasted good though after we scrapped the black off. *
*Pie #2, less burnt and still super good! *
*Plated with a dollop of hand-whipped cream (we don&#8217;t have an electric mixer) *
*Mashed potatoes *
*Food table including Lilly&#8217;s aloe*
*The kotatsu that we ate on/under, it kept us warm and toasty! *
*All the people! *
*Turkey disassembly after all was said and done*
Let’s begin with a gratuitous puppy picture.
Tihar marigolds for sale by the stupa
The city all lit up
Mouthy Girl enjoying her Kukur Tihar
Street dogs all dressed up for their fancy meal
A large-ish sand mandala for Laxmi Puja
Bhaaii Tikka
Momos!
We continue to teach weekly swing dance classes.
Reaching in&#8230;
Ooh la la.
Those are totally mountains! (Photo taken through binoculars)
Outside of the AirBNB house, we had the whole thing to ourselves.
Traditional grills have live coals under a wire grill and people use metal tongs to grill the food
Gyūtan with the usual cuts to make the meat a little more edible. Yakiniku gyūtan is usually cut pretty thin to allow it cook faster, though we&#8217;ve gotten it thick like this at places before
View as you walk up to the cathedral. It used to be on a hill overlooking the city, but then the city came up and engulfed the church.

Iconostasis inside. The choir stands off on the right, and confessions happen on the left before the service starts. Also, the reliquary at the edge on the right side of the picture has a relic of St. Nicholas of Japan for people to venerate.
Selfie overlooking a channel as we were walking to Akihabara
A free Neo-Geo (no coins required) tucked away in a small shop in Akihabara
This building at the Ueno Park shrine has clearly had a new copper roof put on. Nice and shiny!
Koedo at night, lots of old wooden buildings!
Large numbers of people passed through on their way
A random chicken pecking around for bugs
The colorful decorations of the maidens were quite striking
Groups are accompanied by up to four men to supervise and keep them safe on the journey
The girls were clearly having fun and many excitedly wanted to be photographed
Arian sitting there oh-so-casually
Karen resting in the shade
Not sure what this, but it&#8217;s on the cover of the Eswatini Visitor&#8217;s Guide so it must be special!
Look at that! You see those zebras right? Just a few hundred meters away but still just specks in the picture.
Piles of rocks were used for trail markers in a number of places. In case you can&#8217;t tell the where the animal paths lead&#8230;
You can see the water flowing toward the right. You can&#8217;t tell, but it&#8217;s quite a bit farther down to get there. This is why a need a good 3d camera&#8230;
Peeking over the cliff edge we can see the waterfall way down below. Any farther down would feel 10x worse going back up!
Some of the rocks with interesting cracks
About six khumbis passed us the other direction before one came our way!
Beard trimming on our balcony
Beautiful monsoon light and a rainbow
Sunrise from our front window
On the road to Ishinomaki
I worked hard to piece this together from offhand comments spread out over several days.
Khenpo leads the chanting in a low, rhythmic voice.
A representative homework assignment. My handwriting is a bit messy because I wrote on my lap.
